text: in Saudi Arabia hours after a major
purge of the kingdom's political and
business leadership a senior Saudi
prince and seven other officials have
been killed in a helicopter crash near
the country's border with Yemen Prince
Mansour bin McKean the deputy governor
of hazir province was returning from an
inspection tour when his aircraft came
down as yet no cause for the crash has
been given this is according to Saudi
Arabia's interior minister well in that
purge an anti-corruption body led by
Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered
the detentions of dozens of people
including 11 Prince's for ministers and
dozens of former ministers well let's
discuss all of this now with Jane
Kinmont senior research fellow at the
Chatham House think-tank oh good
afternoon to you Jane does the crown
prince feel under threat is this why
he's taken this course of action I think
this course of action indicates the
extent of which he has already
centralized power in his or her hands
previously he would not have felt
capable of arresting quite so many
influential political royal media and
business figures but it's important that
earlier this year he overthrew the
former Crown Prince who was the interior
minister and he has much more direct
control now over the Interior Ministry
one of the factors that helped him to
make these controversial arrests and
what do you make of a speculation
wondering whether there is any
connection between this purge and the
and the helicopter crash who knows it's
very difficult to tell the prince who
died was the son of a former Crown
Prince Prince Makran and the purge has
involved pushing many of the sons of
former kings or preferences else both
power but that hasn't generally applied
to the sons of Makran one of them indeed
has taken over as the head of the
national guard so it's not clear that
there was any particular analyst
towards this individual Clinton we don't
really have enough information to go on
and what do you know about public
reaction to the took to what Crown
Prince Mohammed bin Salman has done in
the last couple of days it's like me
that this is pretty popular it would not
be popular within the royal family of
course many people will wonder who is
next because the mix of corruption and
nepotism and paid homage is deeply
entrenched and widespread in the Saudi
ruling system but among the general
public there's long been frustrating
with a perception that the country is
corrupt that it's nepotistic that there
is not equality of opportunity and so
many are likely to be glad to see very
senior people being as they see it held
accountable of course we can't measure
public opinion exactly because it's very
difficult for people to criticize the
crown prince and indeed the country has
tightened its anti-terrorism laws and
defines defaming the king or train
Prince as terrorism effective offense
which is punishable by up to 10 years in
prison so we're seeing a lot of cheering
for the moves on social media and anyone
who does have doubts is generally
choosing not to speak up ok Jane thank
you very much Jane CaroMont from Chatham
House
